div.head: Ad LECTOREM, De Libelli hujus usu.
div.p: POst tot Sylvas, Calligraphias, & quas ubivis metere est Phrasiologiae messes, sera jam atque supervacanea foret haec racematio sive spicilegium: nisi aliam, quam vulgo solet, rationem ejus inijsset consilium, ut spero, sanius; alium percepisset fructum felicior, 〈◊〉 f • ll • r, usus. Quem, quia ordinis mei viris aliquot • lim desiderantibus approbavi, jam desiderium ejus vel non sentientibus, ne praxin invidere videar, (nisi fortasse, quo sum supercilio, contemnant potiùs) non pigebit septimae huic Edi • ioni praefigere. Planipedes Linguae Lat. tyrones, quos jam certo, fecundum s • nae structurae canonae, pede terram figer • : 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 inst •• uerit, quique ad exercitationis palum promovendividentur, ut discant grande loqui, nitique cot •• rno; omissis alijs, ad tempus, libris, fasciculum hunc in manus sumant, serióque hoc agant. Vbi titulum illis unum pluresve exposuerit praeceptor; ubi phras • um, unde, à qua tra • slatione, ritu, edagióve ducant originem quasi digito commonstrârit; continuatum aliquem sensum concipiat. Huic, quâ sponte, quâ vi, praelectarum phrasium centonem inferciat, tanquam si placeat typus iste, ex titule.

div.head: To take paines.
div.p:
Art thou desirous of profit, praise, pleasure, or knowledge? take paines, watch, studie, leave nothing unattempted. Paines by day and by night is not onely to be devoured, but to bee digested by thee. No garland is given to the sluggard. God selleth all things to man for labour. The Husbandman toyleth, and doth his earnest endeavour, hee workes out huge and almost Herculean labours, that after many moneths he may reape the fruits of his hard labour. The Sayler
with sayles and oares makes to the Haven through many dangers of the Sea. Artificers passe the nights without sleepe, beat the anvile day and night, bend all the sinewes of their body, and forces of their witte, and move every stone, that they may know their art perfectly. The Scholar, the continuall Souldier of wisedome, watches by C • eanthes Lampe, drinkes in the smoke of candle light studies, devotes his whole endeavour to studies; that at length he may furnish his minde with all kinde of knowledge. Certainely God (as the Poet saith) hath set sweat before vertue; neither may any man enter into the inner Temple of Honour, but by the transitory Temple of Vertue.

Hujusmodi proponat illis, peromnes libelli istius paginas & partes, dictata Latinè vertenda, singula idiomate suo propriáque phrasi reddenda. Quibus confectis spacijs, ad secundas curas se accinget, ad praxin secundam illos revocabit. Vti super themate dato Chreias conficiant, nullo non commate phrasi suâ insignito. Idque per titulos omnes capacis sequacísque argumenti fiat. Ab hoc usu vel puer exercitatus probè, non pigmenta accers • visse, non adscivisse pluma • , non purpureum unum & alterum adfuisse pa • n • m: verùm ipsos, unde sumptae apparebunt phrases istae, autores penitus decoxisse, & in sanguinem succúmque suum vertisse videbitur.
